description: Fusion of Middle English redden (“to save, rescue, deliver, rid, free, clear”), from Old English hreddan (“to save, deliver, recover, rescue”), from Proto-Germanic *hradjaną and Middle English reden (“to clean up, clear”), from Old English ġerǣdan (“to put in order, arrange, prepare”), from Proto-Germanic *garaidijaną (“to arrange”). More at rid, ready.

verbs.description: redd (third-person singular simple present redds, present participle redding, simple past and past participle redd or redded)

entries.meaning: (Scotland and Northern England) To fix boundaries.
(Scotland and Northern England) To comb hair.
(Scotland and Northern England) To separate combatants.
(Scotland and Northern England) To settle, usually a quarrel.
(Scotland and Northern England) To tidy up, clear away  Suggest related to Norwegian å rydde. To tidy, clear away

description: From Middle English, from Old Norse ryðja, Middle Low German, compare Dutch redden. In modern use probably actually a back-formation from ready.

verbs.description: redd (third-person singular simple present redds, present participle redding, simple past and past participle redded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Pennsylvania) To clean, tidy up, to put in order.
examples: I've got to redd up the place before your mother gets back.

description: Origin obscure, possibly from the act of the fish scooping, clearing out a spawning place, see redd above.

entries.meaning: A spawning nest made by a fish.
examples: A female chinook salmon digs her redd, or nest, prior to spawning in Oregon's John Day River.

description: From the archaic verb rede or read.

entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of rede
(obsolete) simple past tense and past participle of read
examples: Verrelie that which I have heard and redd in the woorde of God
